title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Welcome

Today’s goal: become confident using AI to accelerate data analysis.


What we’ll do (4 hours):
 Foundations of how AI works
 Gemini capabilities + tokens + pricing basics
 Prompting patterns for ornithological analysis
 Hands‑on labs with SFBBO survey datasets
 Building reusable analysis workflows

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Workshop Agenda (4 Hours)


Hour 1 — Foundations
 AI/LLM basics, tokens, context windows
 Gemini model family and safety

Hour 2 — Prompting for Analysis
 Data understanding, EDA prompts
 Asking for charts, summaries, and insights

Hour 3 — Tooling + Workflows
 CSV + notebook workflows
 Iterative refinement and validation

Hour 4 — Capstone + Q&A
 Mini‑project and best practices
 Pitfalls, governance, next steps

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end, you will:
 Explain what tokens and context windows are
 Craft high‑quality prompts for bird data analysis tasks
 Build a repeatable analysis workflow with Gemini
 Validate outputs and reduce hallucinations

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Poll: Your AI Experience

  Have you used AI tools (ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude)?
  
     Yes, regularly
     Yes, once or twice
     No, never
     Not sure

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What is Gemini?
Gemini is Google’s family of multimodal AI models that can reason over text, code, and structured data (and more).

Key strengths for SFBBO staff:
 Summarization — distill years of survey data
 Pattern detection — find migration trends
 Code generation — automate data cleaning
 Narrative storytelling — write reports and grant summaries

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: AI vs LLM: What’s the Difference?
text:
AI vs LLM: What’s the Difference?
AI (Artificial Intelligence) is a broad field:
 Any technology that performs tasks humans usually do
 Includes chatbots, recommendation engines, image recognition, game-playing bots

LLM (Large Language Model) is a specific type of AI:
 Uses text data to understand and generate language
 Trained on billions of words from the internet, books, code, etc.
 Gemini, ChatGPT, and Claude are all LLMs


Think of it like birdwatching: All LLMs are AI, but not all AI is LLMs—just like all shorebirds are birds, but not all birds are shorebirds!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Discuss with Your Neighbor (2 min)

  Which of these is an LLM?
  
     Spotify recommendation
     Google image search
     Gemini
     ChatGPT
  








Tip


Answers: Gemini and ChatGPT are LLMs (both are correct!) Why? They use language understanding, not image recognition or recommendation algorithms.

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 1: Training Data
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 1: Training Data
Step 1: Collect massive amounts of text
 Billions of pages from the internet, books, research papers, code repositories
 Remove spam, personal data, and low-quality text
 Curate a balanced dataset covering many topics

Why this matters: - Quality data = better understanding of language patterns - Diverse data = model works across many domains (including ornithology!) - Quantity = model learns more nuanced patterns

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 2: Training Process
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 2: Training Process
Step 2: The model learns through prediction
Imagine teaching a bird watcher to identify species. You show examples:
"This small brown bird with a ___ is a House Sparrow."
The model learns: “The blank word should be ‘curved bill’ or ‘striped head’.”

Same concept for LLMs:

Show the model: “The Dunlin (Calidris alpina) is a small ___”
Model predicts: “shorebird”
If wrong, adjust so it gets better next time
Repeat billions of times



This teaches the model patterns about what words go together and what makes sense.

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 3: Fine-tuning & Safety
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 3: Fine-tuning & Safety
Step 3: Make it helpful and safe
 Human experts label examples of good vs. bad responses
 Train the model to prefer helpful, accurate, honest answers
 Add safeguards against harmful outputs

Real example for SFBBO:

Train on bird survey best practices
Reward: “Here’s how to analyze tern breeding success using SFBBO protocols”
Penalize: Made-up conservation statistics

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Summary
The journey from data to AI assistant:



 Gather text data
 Learn patterns through prediction
 Optimize and refine
 Add human feedback
 Safety testing


The model learns to: - Understand context and meaning - Follow instructions - Admit uncertainty - Write in different styles - Reason through problems

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Think-Pair-Share: Real-World Example
Scenario: You ask Gemini: “List all Dunlin observations in SFBBO’s 2024 database.”

Think (30 sec): What could go wrong?


Pair (1 min): Turn to a neighbor and share concerns.


Share: Let’s hear 2-3 concerns…








Warning


Key insight: Gemini can’t access SFBBO’s private database—it only knows what you tell it. Always provide your data explicitly!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Can Do Well
 Text understanding & analysis - Summarize SFBBO survey notes - Extract key information from datasets

 Writing & communication - Draft reports, grant proposals, newsletters - Generate multiple versions or reframings


 Coding & automation - Write Python/R code for data cleaning - Generate SQL queries for databases


 Brainstorming & patterns - Suggest research directions - Identify correlations in data

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Cannot Do
 Access real-time information - No internet browsing (unless specifically enabled) - Doesn’t know events after training date - Can’t check current SFBBO monitoring sites

 Perform complex math reliably - May make arithmetic errors - Struggles with multi-step calculations - Always verify statistics yourself!


 Have personal experiences or emotions - Can’t actually go birdwatching - Can’t feel passion for conservation - Simulates understanding, doesn’t truly “know”


 Access external data without you providing it - Doesn’t have access to SFBBO’s internal databases - Can’t pull up historical records on its own - You must share the data to analyze

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Cannot Do (cont.)
 Guarantee accuracy or avoid hallucinations - Can confidently state false information - May invent citations or statistics - Always fact-check outputs!

 Understand context you don’t explicitly provide - Doesn’t know SFBBO protocols unless you explain them - Doesn’t know your local bird species distributions - Works best when you give complete context


 Make final scientific decisions - LLM suggestions need expert review - Should inform, not replace, your expertise - Always validate with field data

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Check: Spot the Hallucination

  Which statement about California Gulls is FALSE?
  
    1. State bird of Utah
    2. Nest exclusively on SF Bay islands
    3. Medium-sized gull with yellow-green legs
    4. Population stable since 1980
  








Warning


Answers: #2 (they nest inland at lakes, not exclusively on Bay islands) and #4 (populations have fluctuated significantly!)
Even confident-sounding facts about local species need verification!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
LLM Capabilities & Limitations — Quick Reference








Task
LLM Capability
Your Role




Summarize survey data
 Excellent
Review for accuracy


Analyze bird counts
 Good
Validate statistics


Write grants or reports
 Excellent
Edit and fact-check


Generate analysis code
 Good
Test and verify


Real-time species alerts
 Cannot do
You must set up


Complex statistical tests
 Risky
You should code/verify


Interpret species biology
 Good
Confirm with literature


Make conservation decisions
 Cannot do
That’s your expertise

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Poll: Which Would YOU Trust Gemini With?
text:
Poll: Which Would YOU Trust Gemini With?

  Which task would you trust Gemini with?
  
     Drafting a grant
     Writing Python code
     Statistical analysis
     Conservation decisions

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
How AI Works (High‑Level)
LLMs are trained to predict the next token in a sequence.

They learn statistical patterns from large corpora to generate useful outputs.








Note


You provide: instructions + data + constraints
Model returns: a best‑guess completion

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Tokens, Context, and Cost
 Token ≈ a chunk of text (word piece)
 Context window = max tokens a model can see at once
 Costs scale with input + output tokens

Rule of thumb: \[\text{Cost} \propto \text{input tokens} + \text{output tokens}\]

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Basics
Great prompts include:
 Role — who the model is
 Task — what to do
 Data — input
 Constraints — format, length, method
 Examples — optional but powerful

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Interactive: Build a Prompt Together
Let’s co-create a prompt for Gemini!

I’ll say: “Analyze bird count data.”  Too vague!


Who can help make it better?

What role should Gemini play?
What exactly should it analyze?
What format for output?



Better version: “You are a conservation analyst at SFBBO. Analyze this CSV of shorebird counts. Highlight species with >20% population decline and suggest management actions. Format as bullet points.”

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 1: Prompt Template
 Your Turn: Copy this template and customize for your SFBBO data:


Copy to Gemini

Role: You are an expert ornithologist and data analyst 
working with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory (SFBBO).

Task: Summarize key trends in the bird survey dataset.

Data: <paste CSV or description here>

Constraints:
- Provide 5 bullet-point insights
- Suggest 2 visualization ideas
- Note any data quality issues
- Highlight conservation implications for SF Bay wetlands

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 2: Data Quality Check
 Your Turn: Use Gemini to identify data quality issues in SFBBO survey data.
Copy this prompt and run it in Gemini:


Copy to Gemini

You are a data quality analyst for SFBBO. Review this waterbird survey 
data and identify any potential data quality issues, inconsistencies, 
or anomalies that might affect analysis. Flag anything that seems 
unusual for SF Bay bird surveys.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini Model Options (Overview)
Choose based on your analysis needs:
 Latency — speed for quick queries
 Context length — how much survey data fits
 Cost — budget for large datasets
 Quality — reasoning depth for complex analysis

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Pair Activity: Pick Your Model
Scenario 1: You need to analyze 5 years of SFBBO shorebird counts (~50k rows) to write a grant.
Scenario 2: You’re on a field trip and want a quick summary of today’s sightings.

Discussion: Which Gemini version for each scenario? Talk with your neighbor for 1 minute.








Tip


Scenario 1: Larger model (more reasoning, bigger context). Scenario 2: Faster model (speed matters more).

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Break Reflection
Before we move to prompting, reflect:

What’s one thing Gemini could help you with in your bird work?


(You can write it down—we’ll revisit this in the capstone!)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Hour 2 — Prompting for EDA
Tasks Gemini can help with for SFBBO data:
 Column summaries and data dictionary generation
 Missing value analysis (incomplete surveys)
 Outlier detection (unusual counts, rare species)
 Hypothesis generation (population trends, habitat preferences)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 3: EDA Prompt
 Your Turn: Copy this prompt to analyze SFBBO survey data:


Copy to Gemini

You are an expert ornithologist working with SFBBO (San Francisco Bay 
Bird Observatory). I'm sharing a waterbird survey dataset.

TASK: Perform an exploratory data analysis and provide:

1. **Data Overview**
   - Number of records, date range, locations covered
   - List of species observed with frequency counts

2. **Data Quality Assessment**
   - Missing values by column
   - Potential data entry errors or outliers
   - Consistency issues (e.g., species naming)

3. **Initial Insights**
   - Top 5 most frequently observed species
   - Location with highest species diversity
   - Any notable rare species sightings

4. **Visualization Recommendations**
   - Suggest 3 charts with specific axis mappings
   - Explain what each would reveal about SF Bay bird populations

Output as structured markdown with clear headers.

text:
Exercise 4: Visualization Guidance
 Your Turn: Ask Gemini for specific chart recommendations:


Copy to Gemini

Based on the SFBBO waterbird survey data below, recommend visualizations 
for our annual report.

For each chart, specify:
- Chart type and rationale
- X-axis and Y-axis mappings
- Color encoding (if applicable)
- Key annotations to include
- What ecological question it answers for SF Bay conservation

Focus on:
1. Temporal patterns (migration, seasonality)
2. Spatial distribution (by SFBBO monitoring site)
3. Species composition comparisons across habitats

DATA:
site_name,habitat,total_shorebirds,total_waterfowl,total_waders,survey_count

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 5: Analysis Prompt
Use this prompt with the shorebird dataset (or save for later):


Copy to Gemini

You are an ornithologist at SFBBO analyzing shorebird migration data.

Using the provided dataset, complete these tasks:

1. **Summarize the dataset**
   - Total observations by species and site
   - Weekly survey coverage

2. **Identify 3 patterns or anomalies**
   - Look for unusual count spikes or drops
   - Note any correlation with weather, tide, or moon phase
   - Flag potential data quality issues

3. **Ecological interpretation**
   - What do the patterns suggest about shorebird use of SF Bay?
   - How do counts compare between sites?

4. **Propose 2 conservation-relevant next steps**
   - What additional data would strengthen this analysis?
   - What management questions could this data help answer?

Format: Use headers, bullet points, and bold for key findings.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns — The Big Three
Master these patterns and you’ll level up your prompts:

 Decompose — Break complex tasks into steps


Copy to Gemini

First, summarize species counts by SFBBO monitoring site.
Then, analyze weekly trends for the top 3 shorebird species.
Finally, identify correlations with tide and weather variables.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns — The Big Three (cont.)
 Constrain — Set specific output requirements


Copy to Gemini

Provide exactly 5 bullet points, max 15 words each.
Focus only on shorebird species in the Scolopacidae family.
Use scientific names in parentheses after common names.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns (cont.)
 Verify — Request self-assessment


Copy to Gemini

List your assumptions about the SFBBO dataset.
Rate your confidence (high/medium/low) for each insight.
Note which findings need field verification by SFBBO staff.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Pair Challenge: Apply the Patterns
Task: You want Gemini to analyze tern breeding success.

With a neighbor: - Which pattern would help? (Decompose, Constrain, Verify?) - Why? - How would you apply it?


Answer: Likely all three! Decompose (multiple steps), Constrain (specific metrics), Verify (confidence levels).

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Hour 3 — Tooling + Workflows
Typical SFBBO analysis workflow:

 Load survey data in a notebook
 Use Gemini to generate hypotheses about patterns
 Validate with Python/R code
 Iterate based on results

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What is a CSV File?
CSV = Comma-Separated Values
A simple, universal format for storing tabular data as plain text.

Structure:
species,count,location,date
Dunlin,245,Palo Alto Baylands,2025-01-15
Western Sandpiper,189,Don Edwards NWR,2025-01-15
American Avocet,67,Alviso Marina,2025-01-16


 First row = column headers (field names)
 Each subsequent row = one record (observation)
 Commas separate values within a row
 Can be opened in Excel, Google Sheets, or any text editor

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Why CSV is Great for Data Analysis
text:
Why CSV is Great for Data Analysis


Advantages:
 Universal compatibility
 Human-readable (it’s just text!)
 Small file sizes
 Easy to share and version control
 Works with Python, R, Excel, Gemini

SFBBO Use Cases:
 Export survey data from databases
 Share datasets with collaborators
 Upload to AI tools for analysis
 Load into analysis scripts








Tip


Pro tip: Export your SFBBO survey data as CSV before uploading to Gemini!

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How to Export CSV from Google Sheets
text:
How to Export CSV from Google Sheets
Step-by-step:

 Open your data in Google Sheets
 Click File in the top menu
 Hover over Download
 Select Comma-separated values (.csv)
 File downloads to your computer’s Downloads folder








Note


Note: CSV export only saves the current sheet. If you have multiple tabs, export each one separately.





Alternative: For Excel users, go to File → Save As and choose CSV (Comma delimited)

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: What Can You Upload to Google Gemini?
text:
What Can You Upload to Google Gemini?
Gemini accepts multiple file types for analysis:


 Documents

PDF files (reports, papers)
Word documents (.docx)
Text files (.txt)
Google Docs

 Spreadsheets

CSV files (.csv) 
Excel files (.xlsx)
Google Sheets


 Images

Photos (JPG, PNG)
Screenshots
Scanned documents

 Code

Python, R, JavaScript files
Jupyter notebooks









Note


 For SFBBO data analysis, CSV is typically your best choice!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini File Upload Limits
Current limits (as of 2025):
 Single file: Up to 20MB per file
 Multiple files: Up to 10 files per conversation
 Text extraction: ~100,000 tokens from uploaded files
 Session duration: Files persist for the conversation

Practical implications for SFBBO:

Most survey CSVs are well under 20MB ✓
Can upload multiple years of data ✓
Large multi-year databases may need splitting
Consider summarizing before uploading very large datasets

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How to Upload Data to Gemini
text:
How to Upload Data to Gemini
Step-by-step:

 Go to gemini.google.com
 Click the + or paperclip icon in the chat
 Select your CSV file (or drag and drop)
 Type your analysis prompt
 Send and let Gemini analyze!


Example prompt after uploading:
I've uploaded our SFBBO shorebird survey data. Please:
1. Summarize the dataset structure
2. Identify the top 5 species by total count
3. Note any data quality issues

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Best Practices for Uploading Data
 Privacy & Security

Remove sensitive personal information before uploading
Check your organization’s data sharing policies
Consider anonymizing observer names if needed


 Data Preparation

Clean up obvious errors before uploading
Use consistent date formats (YYYY-MM-DD recommended)
Ensure column headers are clear and descriptive
Remove empty rows at the end of files



 Pro tip: Tell Gemini about your data context — what survey protocol, study area, and time period it covers!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini Can Create Charts & Graphs!
One of Gemini’s powerful features is automatic visualization from your data:
 Line charts — Show trends over time (migration patterns, population changes)
 Bar charts — Compare categories (species counts, site comparisons)
 Pie charts — Show proportions (habitat distribution, species composition)
 Scatter plots — Reveal correlations (temperature vs. bird counts)







Tip


Just ask! Gemini will analyze your data and create appropriate visualizations automatically.

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How to Request Charts from Gemini
text:
How to Request Charts from Gemini
After uploading your CSV, try these prompts:

 For trends:
Create a line chart showing how Dunlin counts change across months.


 For comparisons:
Make a bar chart comparing total bird counts at each monitoring site.


 For relationships:
Create a scatter plot of temperature vs. shorebird count 
and add a trend line.


 For customization:
Create a chart showing species by habitat. Use blue for shorebirds, 
green for waterfowl, and orange for waders.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Chart Generation Tips
Get better visualizations with specific prompts:


Be specific about:
 Chart type you want
 Which columns to use
 X and Y axis labels
 Title for the chart
 Colors (if you have preferences)

Example prompt:
Create a line chart with:
- X-axis: month
- Y-axis: count
- Separate lines for each species
- Title: "Shorebird Migration 2024-25"
- Use a legend








Note


If Gemini’s first chart isn’t quite right, iterate! Ask it to adjust colors, add labels, or change the chart type.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini Can Generate Images Too!
Beyond charts, Gemini can create images using AI image generation:
 Illustrations — Visual aids for presentations and reports
 Infographics — Combine data with visual storytelling
 Artistic renderings — Creative visualizations of concepts
 Diagrams — Explain processes or workflows

Start your prompt with: “Generate an image of…” or “Create an illustration of…”

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Image Generation for SFBBO
Practical uses for bird conservation work:

 Educational materials:
Generate an illustration showing the different habitats 
in San Francisco Bay: mudflats, salt ponds, freshwater 
marshes, and open water, with typical bird species in each.


 Presentation visuals:
Create an infographic showing the shorebird migration 
flyway along the Pacific Coast, highlighting the 
San Francisco Bay as a critical stopover.


 Newsletter graphics:
Generate a watercolor-style illustration of Ridgway's 
Rails in a tidal marsh for our conservation newsletter.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Image Generation Tips
Write better image prompts:


Include in your prompt:
 Subject (what to show)
 Style (photorealistic, watercolor, cartoon, diagram)
 Setting/background
 Mood or lighting
 Purpose (infographic, illustration, etc.)

Example prompt:
Generate a photorealistic image 
of a Western Sandpiper foraging 
on a mudflat at low tide during 
golden hour, with the San Francisco 
Bay in the background.








Warning


Important: AI-generated images should be labeled as such. Don’t use them as substitutes for actual field photos in scientific documentation!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise: Create a Visualization
 Your Turn: Upload one of the sample datasets and ask Gemini to create a chart.
Try this with migration_timeline.csv:


Copy to Gemini

I've uploaded shorebird migration data. Please:

1. Create a line chart showing how bird counts change from 
   September 2024 to April 2025 for each species
   
2. Add a title: "Shorebird Migration Patterns at Palo Alto Baylands"

3. Label the axes clearly

4. Use different colors for each species

5. Explain what patterns you see in the data


Bonus: Ask Gemini to create a second chart type (bar chart, area chart) and compare which shows the pattern better!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Introducing NotebookLM
Another powerful Google AI tool for SFBBO:
NotebookLM is a research assistant that helps you understand complex documents.
 Upload sources — PDFs, Google Docs, Slides, websites, YouTube videos
 Ask questions — Get answers grounded in YOUR sources only
 Get citations — Every response links back to source material
 Audio Overviews — Turn documents into podcast-style discussions!







Tip


Perfect for: Summarizing research papers, annual reports, grant guidelines, and training materials!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What is Audio Overview?
NotebookLM’s Audio Overview feature creates AI-generated podcast-style discussions from your documents.

Two AI hosts will:
 Have a lively conversation about your sources
 Make connections between topics and ideas
 Explain complex concepts in an accessible way
 Create 5-30 minute audio summaries








Note


Great for learning on the go! Download and listen during your commute, while doing fieldwork, or during data entry.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Audio Overview Formats
Choose the format that fits your needs:


 Deep Dive (default)
Two hosts unpack topics in an in-depth conversation
. . .
 The Brief
Single speaker delivers key takeaways in under 2 minutes

 The Critique
Two hosts provide constructive feedback on documents
. . .
 The Debate
Two hosts explore multiple perspectives on a topic


You can also customize:

Length (Shorter, Default, Longer)
Focus topics with a custom prompt
Language (80+ languages supported!)

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How to Create an Audio Overview
text:
How to Create an Audio Overview
Step-by-step:

 Go to notebooklm.google.com
 Create a new notebook
 Add your sources (PDFs, Docs, websites)
 Open the Studio panel
 Select Audio Overview and click Generate
 Download the audio or listen in the browser








Note


Generation takes a few minutes for longer documents. You can work on other things while it processes!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Interactive Mode: Join the Conversation!
New feature: You can now interact with the AI hosts!
 Ask follow-up questions with your voice
 Request clarification on specific topics
 Get personalized answers based on your sources
 Hosts resume the original discussion after answering

To use:

Generate a new Audio Overview
Select Interactive mode
While listening, click Join
Ask your questions when the hosts call on you!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Audio Overviews for SFBBO
Practical use cases for your team:

 Onboarding new staff/volunteers:
Upload: SFBBO survey protocols, species ID guides, safety procedures
Result: Audio training they can listen to before their first field day


 Grant preparation:
Upload: Funding guidelines, RFP documents, past successful proposals
Result: Audio summary of requirements while you draft your application


 Staying current on research:
Upload: Recent shorebird research papers, conservation reports
Result: Podcast-style summary of new findings relevant to SF Bay

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Audio Overviews for SFBBO (cont.)
 Board meeting prep:
Upload: Previous meeting minutes, financial reports, strategic plan
Result: Quick audio briefing before meetings

 Annual report digestion:
Upload: Your own SFBBO annual reports from multiple years
Result: Audio summary highlighting trends and accomplishments


 Partner communications:
Upload: Partner organization reports, collaborative project documents
Result: Stay informed about partner activities while multitasking

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Example: Research Paper Summary
Scenario: You want to understand a new shorebird migration study.


Upload to NotebookLM:

The research paper PDF
SFBBO’s related survey data summary
SF Bay habitat maps

Custom prompt:
Focus on findings relevant to 
San Francisco Bay shorebirds. 
Explain statistical methods 
in simple terms.

Audio Overview will discuss:
 Key findings from the paper
 How results apply to SF Bay
 Connections to your SFBBO data
 Implications for conservation
 Questions for further research


Result: A 15-minute audio summary you can listen to during your commute!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Tips for Better Audio Overviews


Do:
 Upload related documents together
 Use custom prompts to focus topics
 Choose the right format for your goal
 Download for offline listening
 Share with team members

Keep in mind:
 AI voices may have occasional glitches
 Content reflects ONLY your sources
 May take several minutes to generate
 Best for English (other languages available)
 Verify important facts independently








Tip


Pro tip: Create a NotebookLM notebook for each major SFBBO project to keep sources organized!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
More Google AI Tools (No Coding!)
Google has integrated Gemini AI across its Workspace apps:


 Google Docs
 Google Sheets
 Google Slides

 Gmail
 Google Drive
 Google Meet








Note


Access: These features require Google Workspace with Gemini or a Google AI Premium plan. Check with your organization’s IT administrator!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Google Sheets
Analyze SFBBO data directly in your spreadsheets!
 Create tables — Generate organized data from descriptions
 Create formulas — Ask for formulas in plain English
 Build charts — Generate visualizations from your data
 Get insights — Ask questions about patterns in your data
 Perform actions — Sort, filter, format, pivot tables

How to access: Click “Ask Gemini” button in the top right of any Google Sheet.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Sheets: SFBBO Examples
 Ask Gemini in your spreadsheet:

"Create a formula to calculate the total bird count for each species"


"Build a bar chart comparing bird counts across our monitoring sites"


"Summarize the key trends in this survey data"


"Add conditional formatting to highlight counts over 1000 in red"


"Create a pivot table showing species counts by month and location"

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Google Docs
Write, edit, and research without leaving your document!
 Write content — Draft text from descriptions
 Rewrite & refine — Improve clarity, tone, length
 Summarize — Condense long documents
 Generate images — Create visuals for your document
 Reference files — Pull info from Drive files and Gmail

How to access: Click “Ask Gemini” button in the top right of any Google Doc.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Docs: SFBBO Examples
 Use cases for SFBBO staff:

 Grant narratives:
"Write a 200-word project description for our shorebird monitoring program"


 Volunteer communications:
"Draft an email inviting volunteers to our winter waterbird census"


 Meeting notes:
"Summarize the key action items from this meeting document"


 Educational content:
"Rewrite this scientific text at a 6th-grade reading level for our 
youth education program"

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Google Slides
Create presentations faster with AI assistance!
 Generate images — Create custom visuals for slides
 Improve content — Get suggestions for better slides
 Design help — Format and style recommendations
 Summarize — Create slides from documents

SFBBO example:
"Generate an image of shorebirds at a mudflat for my 
conservation presentation"
"Create speaker notes for this slide about migration patterns"

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Gmail
Draft, summarize, and respond to emails efficiently!


Composing:
 Draft new emails from prompts
 Rewrite for tone (formal, casual)
 Elaborate on short notes
 Shorten long emails

Reading:
 Summarize long email threads
 Extract action items
 Suggest responses
 Translate messages


SFBBO example:
"Draft a thank you email to our winter census volunteers, 
highlighting that we counted over 15,000 birds this year"

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini in Google Drive
Search and summarize across all your files!
 Smart search — Find files by describing content
 Summarize files — Get quick overviews of documents
 Ask questions — Query information across multiple files
 Compare documents — Find differences between versions

SFBBO example:
"Summarize our shorebird reports from the last 3 years"
"Find all documents mentioning Ridgway's Rail population trends"

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Google Meet with Gemini
Get more from your meetings!
 Live captions — Real-time transcription
 Meeting notes — Automatic summaries after meetings
 Action items — Extract to-dos from discussions
 Translation — Real-time translated captions

Perfect for:

SFBBO board meetings → automatic minutes
Partner calls → action item tracking

Training sessions → transcripts for reference
Remote volunteer coordination → everyone stays informed

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:

Tool
Best For

Gemini Chat
Data analysis, coding help
Analyze survey datasets


NotebookLM
Research, audio summaries
Digest scientific papers


Sheets + Gemini
Spreadsheet analysis
Survey data formulas & charts


Docs + Gemini
Writing & editing
Grant proposals, reports

Presentations
Board presentations

Email drafting
Donor & volunteer communications


Drive + Gemini
File search & summary
Find past reports


Meet + Gemini
Meeting notes
Automatic meeting minutes

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Real-World Scenario: Would You Catch This?
text:
Real-World Scenario: Would You Catch This?
You ask Gemini: “My bird survey shows a 400% increase in Snowy Egrets from Jan to Feb. Is this migration or climate change?”
Gemini responds: “This dramatic increase suggests climate-driven habitat expansion.”

What’s missing? (Think 30 seconds…)








Warning


Gemini didn’t ask: Did you check your data entry? Is that 4x real? Could it be observer differences? You need to validate first!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Safe and Reliable Use






Important


Always validate AI outputs against your field expertise!




 Cross‑check species IDs and counts with raw data
 Keep prompts specific to SFBBO survey protocols
 Ask for sources or ecological rationale
 Use small, testable analytical steps

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Handling Hallucinations
AI can make mistakes with bird data. Mitigation strategies:
 Provide data explicitly — don’t assume it knows SFBBO protocols
 Ask for uncertainty — “How confident are you?”
 Request calculations — have it show the math
 Validate with code — quick sanity checks

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 6: Uncertainty Prompt
 Your Turn:


Copy to Gemini

Analyze this SFBBO bird count data. For each conclusion:
- State your confidence level (high/medium/low)
- Explain what evidence supports it
- Note what could disprove it
- Identify what additional SFBBO data would help confirm the finding

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 7: Structured Checklist
 Your Turn: Convert a narrative prompt into a structured checklist prompt.

Before (vague):
Analyze the Ridgway's Rail population data.


After (structured):


Copy to Gemini

Analyze Ridgway's Rail (Rallus obsoletus) survey data from SFBBO's 
long-term monitoring program.

Complete this checklist:
□ 1) Define the population metric (individuals, breeding pairs, or call responses)
□ 2) Calculate year-over-year population change (%) for each marsh
□ 3) Segment by region (North Bay vs. South Bay)
□ 4) Identify peak detection months
□ 5) Flag any surveys with zero detections (potential concern)
□ 6) Note correlation with tide levels during surveys
□ 7) Compare with historical SFBBO baselines if patterns emerge

Output format: Numbered findings with supporting statistics.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 8: Capstone Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are a wildlife data analyst at SFBBO (San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory).

PROJECT: Waterfowl Population Trends Analysis

CONTEXT:
- Data source: SFBBO annual January waterfowl census
- Time period: 2021-2025
- Goal: Inform wetland management and conservation decisions

ANALYSIS REQUIRED:

1. **Trend Analysis**
   - Calculate year-over-year changes for each species
   - Identify any concerning declines (>20%) or notable increases
   - Note the 5-year trend direction for each species

2. **Habitat Comparison**
   - Compare waterfowl use between freshwater and salt pond habitats
   - Identify which species show habitat preferences

3. **Disturbance Assessment**
   - Correlate counts with human disturbance levels
   - Assess impact of water level changes
   - Recommend management interventions

4. **Conservation Recommendations**
   - Prioritize species/sites for enhanced monitoring
   - Suggest habitat improvements
   - Identify data gaps for SFBBO to address

OUTPUT: Executive summary (1 page) + detailed findings with statistics.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 9: Raptor Analysis Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are an ornithologist at SFBBO analyzing fall raptor migration data 
from Hawk Hill in the Marin Headlands.

Using the dataset, provide:

1. **Migration Summary**
   - Total count by species
   - Peak migration dates for each species
   - Species diversity and dominance patterns

2. **Weather Correlations**
   - How do wind direction and speed affect flight counts?
   - Does visibility or cloud cover impact detection?
   - Identify optimal survey conditions

3. **Temporal Patterns**
   - Compare morning vs. midday vs. afternoon flights
   - Weekly trends through the season
   - Any notable late-season observations?

4. **Conservation Insights**
   - Which species should SFBBO prioritize for monitoring?
   - Are any species showing unusual patterns?
   - Recommendations for next year's survey effort

Format as a structured report suitable for SFBBO's newsletter.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 10: Breeding Analysis Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are analyzing SFBBO's breeding bird territory mapping data.

Provide a comprehensive breeding season summary:

1. **Nesting Success Overview**
   - Calculate nest success rate by species (% with confirmed nests)
   - Calculate productivity (fledglings per successful nest)
   - Identify most and least successful species

2. **Habitat Analysis**
   - Compare success rates across habitat types
   - Calculate average territory size by species
   - Which habitats support highest species diversity?

3. **Threat Assessment**
   - Categorize and quantify threats
   - Which species/sites face highest threat levels?
   - Correlation between threats and nest failure

4. **Site Comparison**
   - Rank SFBBO sites by breeding bird diversity
   - Identify sites with conservation concern
   - Recommend priority sites for protection

5. **Management Recommendations**
   - Actions to improve nest success
   - Threat mitigation strategies
   - Data collection improvements for next season

Output as a formal report suitable for SFBBO's annual summary.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompt Engineering Cheatsheet






Remember: Clarity > cleverness







 State the desired output format explicitly
 Provide all necessary SFBBO data (don’t assume knowledge)
 Specify time period, site, and species scope
 Ask for confidence levels and assumptions
 Request specific numbers, not vague qualifiers

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Data Cleaning


Copy to Gemini

Review this SFBBO bird survey CSV for data quality issues. 

Flag the following:
- Duplicate records (same date, site, species, count)
- Impossible counts (negative or >10,000 for non-colonial species)
- Misspelled species names or invalid species codes
- Dates outside the survey period
- Missing required fields (date, site, species, count)
- Inconsistent site naming

Output as a table of issues with row numbers, issue type, and suggested fixes.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Summary Stats


Copy to Gemini

Calculate for each species in this SFBBO dataset:
- Total count across all surveys
- Mean count per survey
- Standard deviation
- Minimum and maximum counts
- Number of surveys where detected (frequency of occurrence)
- Percentage of surveys with detections

Format as a markdown table sorted by total count descending.
Include a brief interpretation highlighting:
- Most abundant species
- Most consistently detected species
- Species with high variability (potential concern)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Conservation


Copy to Gemini

Based on these SFBBO population trends, identify:

1. **Species of Conservation Concern**
   - Any species declining >15% year-over-year
   - Species with high count variability (CV > 50%)
   - Species absent from historical sites

2. **Potential Causes**
   - Habitat changes at SFBBO monitoring sites
   - Weather/climate factors affecting SF Bay
   - Human disturbance patterns

3. **Recommended Actions**
   - Priority species for enhanced SFBBO monitoring
   - Sites needing management intervention
   - Data collection protocol improvements

Cite specific numbers from the data to support each conclusion.
Reference SFBBO's conservation mission where relevant.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Using Gemini for Grant Writing
Gemini can accelerate your grant application process:
 Draft proposals — Generate initial text from your data insights
 Improve writing — Refine language for clarity and impact
 Research alignment — Connect your work to funding priorities
 Budget justifications — Articulate why resources are needed
 Review checklists — Ensure all requirements are addressed







Tip


Key insight: Use Gemini to draft, but always personalize with SFBBO’s unique voice and mission!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Grant Writing Prompts
 Project Summary:


Copy to Gemini

Write a 250-word project summary for a conservation grant application.

Project: Long-term shorebird monitoring at San Francisco Bay
Organization: San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory (SFBBO)
Key data: [paste your summary statistics]
Goals: Track population trends, inform wetland management
Audience: Wildlife conservation foundation

Emphasize: Scientific rigor, community engagement, measurable outcomes


 Significance Statement:


Copy to Gemini

Write a compelling significance statement (150 words) explaining 
why monitoring shorebird populations in SF Bay matters for:
- Pacific Flyway conservation
- Climate change adaptation
- Urban wildlife management
- Community science engagement

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Grant Writing Prompts (cont.)
 Methods Section:


Copy to Gemini

Draft a methods section for a grant proposal based on SFBBO's 
survey protocols:

Data collection: Monthly point counts at 12 wetland sites
Species: Shorebirds, waterfowl, and marsh birds
Variables: Species, count, habitat, tide level, weather
Analysis: Trend analysis, habitat modeling, population estimates
Timeline: 3-year monitoring period

Write in formal scientific grant language (300 words).


 Budget Narrative:


Copy to Gemini

Write a budget justification for these line items:
- Field technician (0.5 FTE): $35,000
- Equipment (spotting scopes, GPS): $5,000
- Travel to survey sites: $3,000
- Data management: $2,000

Explain why each expense is necessary for shorebird monitoring success.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Finding Research Opportunities
Ask Gemini to help identify funding sources:


Copy to Gemini

I work at San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory (SFBBO), a nonprofit 
focused on bird conservation and research in the SF Bay Area.

Our programs include:
- Long-term waterbird monitoring
- Ridgway's Rail population surveys
- Shorebird migration tracking
- Community science training

Suggest 10 potential grant opportunities from:
- Federal agencies (USFWS, NOAA, EPA)
- State agencies (CA Dept of Fish & Wildlife)
- Private foundations (conservation-focused)
- Corporate giving programs

For each, note: typical award size, deadline cycle, and fit with our work.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Research Collaboration Ideas
 Generate research questions:


Copy to Gemini

Based on SFBBO's 20+ years of waterbird monitoring data, 
suggest 5 research questions that could lead to:
- Peer-reviewed publications
- Graduate student thesis projects
- Collaborative studies with universities

Consider topics like:
- Climate change impacts on SF Bay birds
- Habitat restoration effectiveness
- Urban wetland conservation
- Shorebird migration phenology

For each question, suggest potential academic partners in the Bay Area.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Annual Report Assistance
 Executive Summary:


Copy to Gemini

Write an executive summary (300 words) for SFBBO's annual report.

Key accomplishments this year:
- Monitored 45 wetland sites
- Recorded 125 bird species
- Trained 50 community scientists
- Published 2 peer-reviewed papers
- Received $150,000 in grants

Highlights from the data:
[paste your key findings here]

Tone: Professional but accessible, celebratory but scientifically grounded
Audience: Donors, partners, and the general public


 Donor Thank You Letters:


Copy to Gemini

Write a thank you letter template for SFBBO donors that:
- Acknowledges their specific contribution
- Shares one compelling data point from this year's surveys
- Describes the impact of their support
- Invites them to an upcoming field trip or event

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Newsletter & Outreach Content


 Newsletter Articles:


Copy to Gemini

Write a 400-word newsletter article 
about spring shorebird migration 
in SF Bay for SFBBO supporters.

Include:
- Which species to look for
- Peak timing (based on our data)
- Best viewing locations
- How SFBBO monitors migration

Tone: Engaging, educational, 
inspiring action


 Social Media:


Copy to Gemini

Create 5 social media posts 
about SFBBO's winter waterbird 
census results.

For each post include:
- Hook (attention-grabbing fact)
- Key finding from the data
- Call to action
- Suggested hashtags

Platform: Twitter/X (280 chars)

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Tips for Grant & Research Writing with AI
text:
Tips for Grant & Research Writing with AI






Best Practices








Do:
 Provide specific data and context
 Ask for multiple draft versions
 Edit heavily to match your voice
 Fact-check all statistics
 Add SFBBO-specific details

Don’t:
 Submit AI text without editing
 Let AI invent data or citations
 Use generic language
 Skip the review process
 Forget to acknowledge AI use








Note


Pro tip: Tell Gemini to write in SFBBO’s voice by providing examples of past successful proposals!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Governance and Ethics






Data Responsibility for SFBBO






 Avoid sharing sensitive location data (rare species nest sites)
 Follow SFBBO’s data sharing policies
 Document AI model usage in methods sections
 Keep SFBBO scientists in the loop for all conclusions

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Final Reflection: Your AI Journey

  How do you feel about using Gemini for your bird work?
  
     Confident
     Curious - want practice
     Still learning
     Need more guidance

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Closing + Resources
Next steps for your SFBBO work:
 Practice with your own SFBBO survey datasets
 Build a prompt library for common analyses
 Share learnings with the SFBBO team
 Integrate Gemini into eBird and SFBBO data workflows

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Action Items: Go Forth!
This week, try:


Ask Gemini to summarize one SFBBO dataset




Use one of the three prompting patterns we learned




Validate the output—did it match reality?




Share your experience with the SFBBO team

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Thank You

Happy birding and AI-powered data analysis! 


Questions? Discussion? 


Learn more at sfbbo.org
